Justification: To confirm the diagnosis of diabetes and assess the baseline glucose level.
To evaluate long-term glucose control and confirm the diagnosis of diabetes.
To check for glucose and ketones in the urine, which can indicate poor glucose control and possible diabetic ketoacidosis.
To assess for any underlying infections or other hematological issues that may contribute to fatigue.
To evaluate kidney function and electrolyte levels, which can be affected by diabetes.
To assess cardiovascular risk factors, as diabetes can affect lipid metabolism.
To rule out thyroid disorders that can cause fatigue and other symptoms.
To determine endogenous insulin production and differentiate between type 1 and type 2 diabetes.
